toc_entry.title: 1987 Bum Steer Awards
toc_entry.description: A year of anguished arabs, bigshot bankrupts, crazy cookbooks, despoiled dinosaurs, exhibitionist editors, foiled fugitives, greens-eating graduates, half-cocked hashish, in flagrante inmates, jolly jailers, kinky kilocycles, late lobsters, moistened mayors, and northbound Nicaraguans.

toc_entry.title: Between a Hard Rock And a Place
toc_entry.description: The world’s hottest restaurant chain turns into Texas’ hottest restaurant feud.

toc_entry.title: Total Hit
toc_entry.description: One morning last august, a San antonio patrolman told his superior officer that his best friend was a killer cop. By that afternoon, the killer cop was dead, the patrolman was claiming self-defense, and a city infamous for strange killings was in the midst of one of the strangest of all.

toc_entry.title: The Coronary Bypass
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: In Texas, survivors of this life-and-death operation wear their scars like medals of honor.

toc_entry.title: No Promises
toc_entry.description: I arrived in Houston at the height of the boom, and left just as the bust began. Along the way I learned what it means to grow up.

toc_entry.title: The National Tour Of Texas
toc_entry.description: I’ve long dreamed of driving every highway in Texas. This year i’m doing it —all 32,000 miles worth.

toc_entry.title: The Left Side Of the Menu
toc_entry.subtitle: Food
toc_entry.description: Admit it. The first courses always seem more interesting than the entrees. Why not make a meal of them?.

toc_entry.title: Science Marches On
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: UT historian William Goetzmann traces america’s belief in endless possibilities to the boundless curiosity of its earliest explorers.

toc_entry.title: You May Not Need It, But You Gotta Have It
toc_entry.subtitle: Shopping
toc_entry.description: Arresta is a toy store for grown-ups, where every item is selected to seduce the slavishly stylish.

toc_entry.title: What’s the Sound Of One Texan Meditating?
toc_entry.subtitle: Religion
toc_entry.description: John Toler switched from advertising to Zen, Emerson to Buddha, and Lubbock to the Land of the Lotus.

toc_entry.title: The Three Sisters
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: Crimes of the Heart is a warm spill of sunshine, but Betty Blue is a mindless lump of misery and ;Three amigos! isn’t friendly at all.

toc_entry.title: Enter, With Trumpets
toc_entry.subtitle: Classical Music
toc_entry.description: A series of world premieres commissioned by the Houston Symphony Orchestra has brought a dash of fanfare to Jones Hall.

toc_entry.title: Art Of the People
toc_entry.subtitle: Art
toc_entry.description: An innovative folk art exhibition at the San antonio Museum of art affirms the irrepressible spirit of the Mexican people.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: The citizens of Muleshoe lose their only hospital, thanks to a California chain; the citizens of Houston learn the value of caution, thanks to a local developer; the citizens of the world get a chance to improve their potency, thanks to the aggies.

toc_entry.title: The Quidnunc
toc_entry.description: Celebrating the Day of the Dead with David Byrne; digging for Texas dirt with snoop queen Kitty Kelley; playing nuclear war games in San antonio.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: A gloomy prediction for Texas banks; the oil crisis becomes a steel crisis; how Lloyd Bentsen’s new chairmanship can help Texas.
